p.s: Description of Mycobucterium intermedium sp. nov.
Mycobacterium intermedium (in.ter.me’ di.um. L. neut. adj. intermedium, intermediate, referring to the phylogenetic position of this organism between the rapidly and slowly growing mycobacteria)
Cells are acid-alcohol-fast coccobacilli (2.0 by 2.6 µm).
Does not form spores, capsules, or aerial hyphae.
Visible growth from dilute inocula requires 2 to 3 weeks; colonies on Löwenstein-Jensen agar are eugonic, smooth, photochromogenic, and 3 to 5 mm in diameter.
Growth occurs at 22, 31, 37, and 41°C; optimum growth occurs at temperatures between 31 and 37°C.
Biochemical characteristics are shown in Table 1. M. intermedium synthesizes α-mycolates, α'-mycolates, and keto-mycolates.
A phylogenetic analysis based on an evaluation of 16S rRNA sequences places M. intermedium in an intermediate position between the rapidly and slowly growing mycobacteria (Fig. 3).
Cultures were isolated from the sputum of a patient with pulmonary disease.
Strain 1669/91 is the type strain; a culture of this strain has been deposited in the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen as strain DSM 44049.
